column4: okay
Where are you seeing that you have an EFI partition? While not unheard of it's odd for a computer to come shipped with windows booting via EFI.
: computer management
If you're using EFI you're probably also using GPT, which means there is no need for the hack that is "extended" and "logical" partitions. You can have as many partitions as you want.
: i'll tell you what i'm using.. i just got a asus T101MT eeepc

Ok. I can't find out much information about how EFI is setup on the T101MT eeepc, at this point I'm not even sure if it uses EFI or not. Can you boot an Ubuntu LiveCD and pastebin the output of "sudo blkid"?
... i suppose i could do that... i guess ::p
so what was that command you wanted me to run again?
sudo blkid.
http://paste.ubuntu.com/532814/
interesting?
What is the output of "sudo grub-probe -t partmap -d /dev/sda1"?
msdos

That's unfortunate. Since you aren't using GPT, and the manufacturer of your computer configured it with 4 primary partitions, it's going to be hard to install Ubuntu without losing the ability to user your recovery partition.
i'm guessing that was the efi?
I don't think you're using EFI.
I'm confused what you had me do :p
I had you run one command to give some information about your partitions, and another to tell what type of partition table you're using.
so... if i'm installing onto HDD will i run into issues with dual booting and grub?
: hey remember helping me the other day?
The 24 meg partition is likely the windows "system" partition. It's needed for windows to boot, so do *not* delete it.
